newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli planes strike south of Beirut.
newsitem.headline: Israeli planes strike south of Beirut.

text.p: Israeli planes rocketed Palestinian guerrilla targets in hills south of Beirut on Friday, a Palestinian group said.
Lebanese security sources later confirmed the attack. The Israeli army had no comment on the report.
Two jets fired two rockets into the Na'ameh hills where the radical Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine General Command (PFLP-GC) has bases -- 15 km (nine miles) south of Beirut.

"Israeli U.S.-made F16 warplanes fired at 7:10 pm (1610 GMT) two heavy rockets into administrative, social and medical centres belonging to the PFLP-GC. The rockets caused damage only in the fields," the group said.
"There were no casualties in the attack," it added in a statement faxed to an international news agency in Beirut.
The attack was the 49th Israeli air strike on Lebanon since the beginning of the year.

Earlier, Katyusha rockets slammed into northern Israel, slightly wounding an Israeli woman. Pro-Iranian Hizbollah (Party of God), the most formidable guerrilla force fighting Israeli occupation of south Lebanon, said it did not fire the rockets.
The attacks on Friday came amid the worst cross-border violence in south Lebanon since Israel's 17-day offensive in April last year.
A U.S.-brokered ceasefire understanding which ended the blitz then barred both Hizbollah and Israeli troops from targeting civilians on both sides of the border.
Between Monday and Thursday 13 Lebanese -- including seven civilians -- were killed by bombs, Israeli artillery and Israeli rocket attacks.
One member of the Israeli-backed South Lebanon Army militia was killed by a bomb and Israeli commandos killed five members of Hizbollah with a roadside bomb.
Hizbollah said on Friday it would resume Katyusha rocket attacks on northern Israel because the ceasefire understanding had failed to protect Lebanese civilians.

"We say the understanding has ceased to protect civilians. We say the resumption of using other means to protect civilians has become necessary," Hizbollah secretary-general Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah told a news conference.
"But the timing of using Katyushas to protect civilians has to do with the situation on the field...and a number of other similar considerations," he said.
